sessions.name: IPv4 and IPv6 Routing
sessions.description:
Level of Study: Intermediate

Synopsis

This is a technical workshop, made up of lecture and hands-on lab work to teach the necessary routing protocol and IPv6 skills for networks which make up today's Internet.This workshop is not an introduction. The lab exercises use Cisco IOS configuration syntax.

Target Audience

Technical staff who are now building or operating a wide area service provider network with international and/or multi-provider connectivity, and are considering deploying IPv6 across their infrastructure and to their end users.

Pre-requisites

It is assumed that the workshop participants know how to use a router command line interface, do basic router configuration and have a working knowledge of an IGP (OSPF or IS-IS) and BGP fundamentals.

Course outline

Workshop topics include, but are not limited to:

  • IS-IS design and best practices for Service Provider networks
  • BGP attributes and policy
  • BGP scalability (including Route Reflectors and Communities)
  • Aggregation
  • IPv6 Protocol and Standards
  • IPv6 extensions for routing protocols
  • IPv6 addressing and address planning
  • IPv6 transition techniques
  • IPv6 deployment case study

Other requirements

Hardware: It is highly recommended that participants bring their own laptop computers with Wifi (b/g/n) and administrative access to system to practice the lessons learned during the workshops.

It is also recommended that laptops have Intel i5 or i7 processor, >=8GB of RAM, 30GB of free hard disk space, and a 64-bit operating system (Windows, Linux, or Mac OS X).

Software: SSH Client, Telnet Client

sessions.name: Information Security
sessions.description:
Level of Study

Intermediate

Synopsis

Information Security is a broad topic, and as such this training course will look at several aspects from policies to penetration testing, and DNS to DDoS. Each topic is covered from basics to intermediate level that aims to educate and challenge participants.

This training course will be delivered over 4 days, and will include a mix of theory presentations, hands-on exercises, and group discussions/Q&A.

A certificate of participation will be provided upon successful completion of the course.

Target Audience

Engineers, IT Managers and Operators, and Security Policy Makers who are interested in information security, gaining an understanding of the threats they face and how to mitigate such threats.

Course outline

Topics that will be covered include:

  • Internet, IP, and Routing Basics
  • DNS and Domain Hierarchy
  • Whois Databases
  • Information Security Overview
  • Threat and Countermeasures to Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability
  • Securing Network Infrastructure
  • DDoS Fundamentals and Mitigation
  • Operational Security
  • Security Policies
  • Penetration Testing
  • Password Control – End-User Perspective
  • Password Control – Secure Server Side Storage

Other Requirements

Participants are advised to bring their own laptop computers with high-speed Wi-Fi (802.11a/g/n/ac) and administrative access to system. It is also recommended that laptops have Intel i5 or i7 processor, >=8GB of RAM, 30GB of free hard disk space, and a 64-bit operating system (Windows, Linux, or Mac OS X). Participants are requested to pre-install VirtualBox (free), or VMware Workstation (paid or trial), although installation files will be available at the beginning of the course.

sessions.name: Introduction to Software-defined networking (SDN)
sessions.description:
Level of Study

Intermediate

Synopsis

The emergence of SDN is having a disruptive influence on the world of data networking and is leading to a fundamental re-think of how networks are architected.

This workshop will provide an in-depth understanding of the key technology elements of SDN via a combination of lectures and hands-on exercises.

Target Audience

Anyone currently operating an IP network who is interesting in understanding the impact of SDN with a view to implementing elements of it in the near future.

Pre-requisites

Intermediate-level knowledge of IP routing, routing protocols, management protocols, MPLS protocols, traffic-engineering.

Course outline

  • Market drivers for SDN and NFV
  • Introduction to SDN:
    • History
    • Control and data plane separation
    • Architectural frameworks
    • OpenFlow protocol
    • SDN controller Northbound interfaces
    • Topology discovery and management
    • Centralised traffic engineering
    • SDN controller Southbound interfaces
    • Segment routing
    • Path Computation Element Protocol

Other requirements

Hardware: It is highly recommended that participants bring their own laptop computers with Wifi (b/g/n) and administrative access to system to practice the lessons learned during the workshops.

It is also recommended that laptops have Intel i5 or i7 processor, >=8GB of RAM, 30GB of free hard disk space, and a 64-bit operating system (Windows, Linux, or Mac OS X).

Software: SSH Client, Telnet Client

sessions.name: Network Security
sessions.description:
Level of Study

Intermediate

Synopsis

The objective of this workshop is to examine the key concepts, protocols and the policies involved in establishing and maintaining security and building an understanding and familiarity with their operation. Device and Network infrastructure security is examined with a focus on different layers to establish a robust, stable and secure network and protect the data and processes that occur in the network.

The workshop also looks at the nature and structure of network attacks.

The course further examines the actions and processes that can be used to identify, mitigate and respond to such attacks.

Target Audience

Engineers, Network Managers and Operators, Security policy makers who are interested in network security and gaining an understanding of the threats they face and how to mitigate such threats.

Pre-requisites

It is assumed that participants have a basic understanding of network operations and Internet technologies.

Course outline

  • Threat Models
    • Types of Attackers
    • Network Infrastructure
    • Service Infrastructure (e.g. DNS, email)
    • Users
  • Network Infrastructure
    • Router and Switch Protection
    • Routing Protocol Protection
    • Detecting Sick Hosts and Walling Them
  • Infrastructure Services
    • IDS
    • Firewalls
    • IPv6 Security
    • Anomaly Detection
    • RPKI
  • End User Hosts
    • Mac, Unix, and Linux
    • Keeping Up to Date – Patching
    • Host Based Firewalls
    • Authentication Services
    • PKI Services
    • Checking for Disease: Scanners
    • Preventing Disease: Anti-virus
    • Safe Mail Practices
    • Safe Browsing Practices in Firefox, Chrome, Safari
    • Safe Inter-host Protocols: SSH, RSVC, SFTP and more
    • Personal Encryption of Files and Communications
  • Administrative
    • Security Plan
    • Inter-network Cooperation
      • NOGS
      • CERT
      • FIRST
  • Planning for Future Changes

Other requirements

Hardware: It is highly recommended that participants bring their own laptop computers with Wifi (b/g/n) and administrative access to system to practice the lessons learned during the workshops.

It is also recommended that laptops have Intel i5 or i7 processor, >=8GB of RAM, 30GB of free hard disk space, and a 64-bit operating system (Windows, Linux, or Mac OS X).

Software: SSH Client, Telnet Client

sessions.name: AP* Meeting
sessions.description:
AP* is the Community of Asia Pacific Internet Organisations established in 1998 to provide a strong united front for all Asia Pacific Internet organisations to deal with International issues of governance, administration, management, research, development, education, public awareness of the Internet.

More information about this session is available here.

sessions.name: APIX Meeting
sessions.description:
APIX is the association of Internet Exchange Points in the Asia Pacific Region. It serves as a forum for Internet Exchange Points to exchange experiences. APIX members meet twice a year, at the APNIC and APRICOT conferences.

More information about this session is available here.

agenda.topic: OSINT for the CapEx/OpEx challenged, economy wide CSIRT

agenda.topic: Data driven DNS project to improve cybersecurity

agenda.organisation: Government of the Republic of Vanuatu, OGCIO
agenda.topic: Cyber Security Challenges: The need to Bridge the Gaps

agenda.name: Raja Azrina Raja Othman
agenda.abstract: The ultimate aim in a cyber attack is to gain entry to endpoint systems, be it servers, terminals, or enduser computers.  Once successful, further reconnaissance can be conducted to identify more specific target host and information.  The session will cover on how the endpoint protection has evolved from blacklisting to whitelisting approach in defending against common attacks and the challenges in implementation.

sessions.name: Newcomers Session
sessions.description:
* Invitation only session.

The Newcomers' welcome is an introduction to the APNIC conference for new attendees. Join the session to:

  • Learn about APNIC and APNIC services
  • Learn how to get the most of the conference
  • Take part in Policy SIG mock-up and learn how to engage with the Policy Development Process (PDP)
  • Network with other conference delegates
  • Meet industry experts

This session is by invitation only. The APNIC Secretariat will send personal invitations to the new delegates. There will also be a chance to win a lucky door prize!

agenda.name: Srinivas Chendi
agenda.position: Senior Advisor - Policy and Community Development

agenda.name: Srinivas Chendi
agenda.position: Senior Advisor - Policy and Community Development

agenda.name: Tony Smith
agenda.topic: APNIC Policies that changed the Internet

agenda.name: Srinivas Chendi
agenda.position: Senior Advisor - Policy and Community Development

agenda.name: Entertainment by groupe Nayrouz from Lifou (Lifou is an island of the Loyalty Islands, in the archipelago of New  Caledonia).
Raja Azrina Raja Othman
agenda.topic: The Evolving Threat in the face of Increased Connectivity : Security, Privacy and Safety
agenda.abstract:
As we become more interconnected in a world of ubiquitous computing, the risk of information loss, unauthorised access and modification, abuse and misuse, becomes more prevalent.  This progression of Internet access - from the few to the many - and its prevalence in our daily lives is playing out in its various stages, both socially and economically, across the Asia Pacific.

As connectivity grows, so does the Internet’s influence and impact.  While we acknowledge the need for architects and engineers to put emphasis in ensuring safety in civil works when building skyscrapers and bridges, what is the state of our network, systems and applications, from the aspects of security, privacy and safety?

agenda.name: Jonathan Brewer
agenda.topic: The Connected Pacific: Cables, Satellites, & Metrics
agenda.abstract:
The last five years have been a time of profound change in the Pacific Islands. The most sparsely populated region on the planet has gained new submarine fibre or high throughput satellite to nearly every one of its member states. But what does all this infrastructure mean to the region?

This presentation will walk through the telecommunications environment of the Pacific Islands, examining the impact of recent connectivity developments and the potential for future projects and distinct peering strategies to improve Pacific connectivity.

agenda.name: Srinivas Chendi
agenda.position: Senior Advisor - Policy and Community Development

agenda.name: Guangliang Pan
agenda.topic: NRO Internet Number Resources Status Report

sessions.name: Panel : Satellite Connectivity in the Pacific
sessions.description: Satellite Internet connectivity is often the only option for remote islands in the Pacific. ISPs in the Pacific have several providers and technologies to choose from, but satellite links remain a costly resource that ISPs want to use efficiently. The panel brings together both satellite providers and network engineers to discuss the issues being faced and potential practices that could help provide solutions. Join us with your questions as we look at what providers, ISPs and the Internet community can do in order to improve the experience of end users on satellite connections.

sessions.name: Cooperation SIG: Whois -Challenges of data  protection and privacy
sessions.description:
The Cooperation SIG is a forum for discussion about broader Internet issues like Public Policy and Internet Governance, which are related to APNIC community interests, but which involve governments, other organizations, and other communities. The Secretariat will report to the SIG about APNIC’s outreach activities and seek advice and guidance on future activities. The SIG will act as a forum to develop and clarify the APNIC community's position on issues of relevance to the public sector, or on matters for which a community position has been sought.

Theme: Whois database is an important component of the registry system whether it be Internet number resources or domain names. Specifically, it contains information about the legal entity that holds such resources, comprising the name, postal address, email, telephone and other contact information for the organization/entity.Globally, WHOIS service and protocol is the subject of intensive discussion within (and outside) the numbers as well as in the naming community. Whois data base is structured in a manner, where any one can access the data any time.

However, two developments which have taken place recently , brings the issue of data protection and privacy at the center stage . One is the way Cambridge Analytica breached the data, where millions of personal data was swiped . Another is the European privacy law ,better known as General Data Protection Regulations (GDPR) which may conflict with the way we presently use the data. This may call for a significant change in the way whois data will be structured in the future. Also there will be profound change in the way we access the whois database today. Thus the data (information ) will be subject to varied needs of the privacy, data protection, security, disclosure and access. What information is being collected in the Whois databases? What information is disclosed and protected? And, most importantly, How?

This session will address and would deliberate and discuss these issues with various stakeholders and sensitize the APNIC community to the changing scenario of data protection and growing concern about privacy. The session is expected to examine, How information is being collected in the Whois databases and What information is disclosed and protected?

agenda.name: Bikram Shrestha
agenda.topic: Whois: Challenges of data Protection & Privacy - Nepal Perspective

agenda.name: Savenaca Vocea
agenda.topic: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) & Whois at ICANN
agenda.abstract: Whois before and now. A presentation to highlight some areas of work underway in ICANN as we seek to clarify complying with European Union’s General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and next steps underway.

agenda.name: Guo Feng
agenda.position: Representative of the Chinese government to the GAC of ICANN
agenda.topic: GDPR Discussions With ICANN and GAC

agenda.name: Ila Nitin Gokarn
agenda.abstract: It is forecasted that by 2020, global IP traffic will reach 2.3 zettabytes per year, more than double what we have today. Managing the network manually under these conditions will simply be impossible. This presentation looks at three approaches to automation that can be adopted across an organization and highlights the differences, advantages, and use case examples for each with short demonstrations.

agenda.name: Martin Levy
agenda.abstract:
On April 1st Cloudflare announced the 1.1.1.1 DNS resolver that focuses on privacy. It runs on Cloudflare's global infrastructure (which is presently around 150 sites around the world) making it possibly the largest DNS deployment anywhere!

This talk will describe the relationship between Cloudflare and APNIC Labs regarding Cloudflare's use of the 1.1.1.0/24 & 1.0.0.0/24 IP blocks. It will cover the technical deployment and privacy aspects of the resolver, including: DNS over TLS, DOH, 24 hours of logging (before being deleted), plus the various DNS protocol options that improve privacy. The presentation will also include a review of both the cleanup of 1.1.1.0/24's routing globally, plus the pitfalls of route leaks on that very easy to type address. Finally, the talk will address some of the results from running an open resolver of this scale.

agenda.name: Geoff Huston
agenda.abstract: This presentation looks at the correlation between IPv6 deployment and potential related factors, including GDP, ISP growth and IPv4 address scarcity pressures and looks to see if there is any correlation. Unfortunately there is no strong correlation in any of the tested metrics and we are unsure what common factors propel IPv6 deployment.

sessions.name: Opening reception

sessions.description:
© terre de Lumiere/NCTPS

http://www.adck.nc/

Bus transportation will be provided from Le Meridien Noumea to the venue from 6pm.

The first bus from the Tjibaou Cultural Centre will depart from 21:00.

sessions.name: Panel: CDN Caching
sessions.description: This session is about Content Delivery Networks (CDNs). Goal of this panel discussion is to understand how popular CDNs work, how do they peer or collocate with internet service providers. This also includes CDNs participation at the Internet Exchanges and what expectation ISPs should have from the CDNs and vice versa.

agenda.name: Jethro W Tambeana
agenda.organisation: Office of Government Chief Information Officer (OGCIO) Vanuatu Government

agenda.name: Krishna Prasad Pokhrel
agenda.topic: Community based CDN node & caching hosting
agenda.abstract: Most internet traffic is from Facebook, YouTube or other CDN providers. CDN providers are very interested in hosting their cache servers in large ISPs who have large bandwidth volumes, or they will establish a PoP in those areas where the demand for their service is very high.  From the customer perspective, whether they receive their service from large ISP or small ISP, they want fast and reliable connectivity at a cheaper price. And they want the content near to them so their experience is the same regardless of whether they live in a large city or small town. This presentation talks about a community-based CDN concept that could fill the gaps where large content providers don't have presence.

sessions.name: ASO Review
sessions.description:
The Address Supporting Organisation (ASO) is an entity established in 2004 by a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) among the Internet Corporation of Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) and the Number Resource Organization (NRO). Under the ASO MoU, it is agreed that the NRO fulfils the role, responsibilities and functions of the ASO.

In 2017, the NRO engaged ITEMS International to conduct the second independent review of the ASO. The objective of this review is to determine whether the ASO has a continuing purpose in the ICANN structure, whether any change in structure or operations of the ASO is desirable to improve its effectiveness in the ICANN structure, and additionally whether the ASO is sufficiently accountable to the Internet number community when carrying out its responsibilities.

Following the release of the review report, community consultation sessions were held at APNIC 44 and APRICOT 2018 to discuss the report's findings and the community’s response to the recommendations.This session at APNIC 46 provides another opportunity for community discussion on the ASO Review.

agenda.name: Paul Wilson
agenda.topic: Input from NRO EC on the future of ASO

agenda.name: Jordi Palet
agenda.topic: A new Internet? Intro to HTTP/2, QUIC, DoH and DNS over QUIC
agenda.abstract: This presentation will provide an overview of new protocols which are very relevant to an Internet where we are moving to "all HTTP" traffic, increasing privacy, so a kind of "New Internet". Starting from HTTP/2, the presentation will go through the latest IETF status for QUIC, DNS over HTTP and DNS over QUIC, and compare the approaches.

agenda.name: Martin Winter
agenda.topic: BGP Bugs, Hiccups and weird stuff: Issues seen by RT-BGP Toolkit
agenda.abstract:
This presentation gives a quick introduction to the Realtime BGP Toolkit
from Hurricane Electric and then shows some of the weird BGP issues
discovered on the Internet with it: Outdated standards, buggy software,
configuration typos and just plain wrong announcements.

agenda.name: Anurag Bhatia
agenda.abstract: This presentation is about our experience of using automation in the generation of route server config at BharatIX in Mumbai. It's primarily based on features and use case of open source project - a routeserver.

sessions.name: Lightning Talks
sessions.description:
Lightning talks are short talks/presentations on relevant topics that last no more than 10 minutes, including walking to podium and Q&A. This time limit is strictly enforced. Lightning talks are open to all registered APNIC 46 attendees, and the call for submissions will open when APNIC 46 commences.

Talks on topics that are timely, interesting, or even a little crazy, are invited. The APNIC 46 Programme Committee will evaluate all submissions and choose the best submissions. Talks must be relevant to the Internet Operations community, as per the APNIC 46 CFP Guidelines.

If you've thought about presenting at a future APNIC conference, a lightning talk this year is a great place to start!

agenda.name: Srinivas Chendi
agenda.position: Senior Advisor - Policy and Community Development

agenda.name: Jordi Palet
agenda.abstract: This will introduce a new IPv6 RFC which allows, using SLAAC, to provide a complete /64 to a host interface. This is very interesting for many scenarios for security reasons (hot-spots) or when VMs are being used (data-centers) as well as for enterprises willing to deploy IPv6-only networks with IPv4-as-a-Service.

agenda.name: Dr Ulrich Speidel
agenda.topic: Simulating the behavior of satellite Internet links to small islands

sessions.name: Pacific Internet Development
sessions.description: The Pacific islands region is one of the most diverse and sparsely populated areas on the planet, and faces a range of unique connectivity challenges.  This session looks at some recent projects across the Pacific that are meeting those Internet challenges and delivering significant benefits to island communities.

agenda.name: Stephen Leo
agenda.topic: Vanuatu’s VITAL network to save lives

agenda.name: Dr Basil Leodoro
agenda.topic: Vanuatu’s VITAL network to save lives

sessions.name: IPv6 Readiness Measurement
sessions.description:
The IPv6 Readiness Measurement session was formed at APNIC 36 with TWNIC’s initiative in 2013. Its aim is to encourage organizations that have been working on IPv6 deployment to share their IPv6 readiness measurement methods and outcomes.
IPv6 Readiness Measurement is looking for data that indicates IPv6 readiness in each network, economy and region. Example for:

  • IPv6 allocation and BGP advertisements
  • Data on network traffic over IPv6
  • End user readiness over IPv6
  • DNS queries from ccTLDs over IPv6
  • Web services availability over IPv6
  • Etc.

You can subscribe to the IPv6 Readiness Measurement mailing list to keep engaged and share information at ap-v6readiness@ap-v6readiness.org.

agenda.name: Jordi Palet
agenda.topic: Raiders of the lost Ark (read IPv6 CPE)
agenda.abstract:
In the last years, one of the difficulties for the IPv6 deployment, has been the lack of pressure from the ISPs towards the CPE vendors, in order to provide basic IPv6 features to allow dual-stack and IPv6-in-IPv4 transition mechanisms (as documented by RFC7084).

In many cases, the small and medium ISPs can’t buy quantities that can justify the request of any missing functionalities to the vendors, or even they don't have any contact with them, as they are being sourced locally, either by distributors or even in the retail market.

However, despite this having finally been sorted out, we have a new problem, due to the lack of IPv4 addresses. That means that the previous transition mechanisms are no longer useful in a world that is looking for removing IPv4 in the access network, but still providing IPv4 functionalities to the customers in their LANs. This is being called IPv4-as-a-Service (IPv4aaS) in IPv6-only access networks. So, the previous problem is being reproduced because due to the slow take-up of the IPv6 deployment, now the CPEs need to support new ways to provide IPv6 and IPv4 services.

This presentation will introduce draft-ietf-v6ops-transition-ipv4aas (hopefully already an RFC at the presentation time), differences with RFC7084, how it works from both, the CPE perspective (and thus the CPE vendor) and from the ISP perspective, and how a single firmware feature-set will work in any ISP, even with CPEs acquired via the retail market.

Due to the expected life time of the CPEs (5-10 years) we will look also into possible open source solutions in order to upgrade the CPE firmware and avoid replacing them.

agenda.name: Valentin Ouvrard
agenda.abstract: A container is a lightweight, stand-alone, executable package of a piece of software that includes everything needed to run it: code, runtime, system tools, system libraries, settings. Available for both Linux and Windows based apps, containerized software will always run the same, regardless of the environment. Each containers got his own IP address and talk to each other using different network solution (Overlay or Routing) who can be tricky when dealing with hundred or more containers. Sadly, Containers world is dominated by IPv4, like in many other area. In this lighting talk, we will see how IPv6-only can be used in container orchestration platform (Kubernetes), how it can improve security, reliability and the future of your applications hosting and finally how it can be a bit complicated to set up.

agenda.name: Anurag Bhatia
agenda.topic: IPv6 growth at Hurricane Electric’s AS6939

agenda.name: Jeffrey (Zhaohui) Zhang
agenda.abstract: The Routing in Fat Trees (RIFT) protocol addresses the demands of routing in Clos and Fat-Tree networks via a mixture of both link-state and distance-vector techniques colloquially described as 'link-state towards the spine and distance vector towards the leafs'. RIFT uses this hybrid approach to focus on networks with regular typologies with a high degree of connectivity, a defined directionality, and large scale.

agenda.name: Shishio Tsuchiya
agenda.abstract: Dell Oro Group reports merchant silicon and vendor ASIC portfolio from 2008 to 2018. In 2018, merchant silicon reaches to the transport layer. The presentation explains what is the background in the information from authors experience and knowledge.

agenda.name: Savenaca Vocea
agenda.topic: The New Root Zone DNSSEC KSK
agenda.abstract:
In October 2017, ICANN planned to roll, or change, the “top” pair of cryptographic keys used in the DNSSEC protocol, commonly known as the Root Zone KSK (Key Signing Key). The rollover was postponed but it is coming soon, and network operators using DNSSEC-validating resolvers must update their systems with the new KSK to help ensure trouble-free Internet access for users.

This presentation will provide guidance to network operators about the changes they will need to make to their systems and be ready to roll the KSK.

sessions.name: Community Trainers BoF
sessions.description:
Are you interested in becoming an APNIC Community Trainer?

APNIC invites all existing and prospective Community Trainers to join this BoF session to:

  • Learn more about the program
  • Express your opinions to improve the program
  • Suggest any experts in this field to continue to involve more trainers
  • To list what real operational problems they have in their networks (or know of)
  • Discuss how APNIC can help solve (some) those problems - trainings (both F2F and online-Academy), TAs, etc.

Also we welcome your suggestions to provide maximum benefits to the APNIC Members and the Community for more targeted and operationally relevant trainings.

sessions.name: Data Gathering and Analysis BoF
sessions.description: This BoF is being held for those who are interested in data collection, analysis and reporting, to continue discussions from APNIC 45 about how APNIC community data collection and analysis activities could be designed and conducted. APNIC staff will provide an update on this project.

agenda.topic: RBADT: An RQA Based BGP Anomaly Detection Tool

sessions.name: Tutorial: IPv6-only transition with demo
sessions.description:
This tutorial will introduce the different IPv6-only transition technologies that apply to both, broadband and cellular networks, comparing them and discussing the required steps to deploy IPv6-only with IPv4-in-a-service in an ISP/enterprise network.

The transition mechanisms will include:

  • Dual-stack
  • Tunneling (6RD, DS-Lite, lw4o6, MAP-E, …)
  • Translation (MAP-T, 464XLAT, NAT64, …)

The main effort will be devoted to how to setup NAT64, DNS64 and 464XLAT and the implications for DNSSEC and possible solution approaches, based on the IETF work.

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-v6ops-nat64-deployment/

sessions.name: Policy SIG 2
sessions.description: The charter of the Policy SIG is to develop policies and procedures which relate to the management and use of Internet address resources by APNIC, NIRs, and ISPs within the Asia Pacific region.

agenda.name: Jordi Palet
agenda.topic: prop-125: Validation of "abuse-mailbox" and other IRT emails

sessions.name: Tutorial: Internet of Things
sessions.description: This tutorial provides a technical introduction to the Internet of Things. It begins by discussing core concepts and a class of applications that is enabled by new IoT technologies. It goes on to discuss radio and network protocols for low-power wide area networks, including IETF, 3GPP, SigFox, and LoRaWAN. The idea of publish-subscribe data streams is covered and higher level IoT protocols are introduced, including CoAP, MQTT, REST, and Websockets.

At the AMM, APNIC’s plans, budgets and reports are presented to the community, and questions and feedback to both the EC and APNIC Secretariat are encouraged. NRO NC election results are also announced during the AMM

sessions.name: Campus Network Design and Operations (CNDO)
sessions.description:
Synopsis

Outline

This is a technical workshop, made up of lecture and hands-on lab work to teach the skills needed to design, build, operate and manage a tertiary education insitution's campus network infrastructure according to current best practices.

Workshop Topics

Participants in this course will learn about:

  • Research and Education network infrastructure
  • Campus core infrastructure design best practices
    • Campus design principles
    • Physical infrastructure (cabling and cabling installation)
    • Fibre optics
    • Switching (spanning tree, VLANs, L2 best practices)
    • Routing (static routing and OSPF)
    • IPv4, IPv6 and deploying dual stack infrastructure
    • Choosing campus routers and switches
  • Best practice techniques in core network operations
  • Campus security implementation and best practices
    • Acceptable use policies
    • Monitoring
    • Firewall placement
  • Building sufficient instrumentation to monitor and manage the network

These skills will in turn drive an increase in campus network usability, security and reliability, as well as enhance the usability of the National REN the campus connects to, and improves the connectivity to and engagement with the regional R&E networking community.

Target Audience

The course targets the network & systems engineers from tertiary education institutions (campuses) and National or Regional Research and Education networks (RENs)

Prerequisites

  • Medium to good knowledge of the UNIX/Linux command line environment
  • Basic knowledge of TCP/IP networking
  • Participants are required to bring a laptop

Objectives

At the end of the workshop, students will be able to:

  • Explain the goals associated with fit-for-purpose network design and demonstrate this understanding through successful completion of lab exercises.
  • Explain the different models of a Research and Education Network and be able to share with the class model used or proposed in their economy.
  • Explain physical cabling types, their differences and where they might be best deployed.
  • Explain and demonstrate how to build networks hierarchically using a star topology. Students will be able to present their current network topology and explain how this compares to the star-topology taught in class.
  • Produce a sample addressing plan and present it, plus the underlying design rationale in class.
  • Produce an IP Subnetting and VLAN design for their campus network.

sessions.name: IPv6 Deployment
sessions.description:
Target audience

Technical staff who are involved in Internet technology standards, local and national network infrastructure deployment and day to day network operations.

Prerequisites

It is assumed that the workshop participants know how to use a router command line interface, do basic router configuration and have a working knowledge of an IGP (OSPF or ISIS) and BGP fundamentals. Knowledge of the IPv6 protocol is helpful but not essential.

This workshop is not an introduction. The lab exercises use Cisco IOS configuration syntax.

Participants are required to bring their own laptops. These can be Windows/Linux/macOS and must have working wireless to allow participation in the hands on lab exercises.

Workshop Topics

  1. Internet Fundamentals
  2. Routing Protocols - IS-IS and BGP
  3. IPv6 Protocol and Standards
  4. IPv6 Enhancements to Internet Routing Protocols
  5. IPv6 addressing and Building IPv6 Address Plans
  6. Securing and Hardening IPv6 Networks and Devices
  7. IPv6 transition technologies including dual stack, 6rd, DS-Lite, 464XLAT, NAT64
  8. IPv6 deployment case study
  9. IPv6 in 3G/4G mobile networks

agenda.name: Simon Sohel Baroi
agenda.topic: Whois: Challenges of data Protection & Privacy - Nepal Perspective
agenda.abstract: In 2018, we had a big discussion on the content blocking in Japan. In April the Cabinet of Japan ratified its intent that for the purpose to suppress the influence of content piracy web site the content blocking should preferably done at access providers, which is possibly interpreted that they are effectively requested to do it.  After that a governmental Task Force was formed involving attorneys, publishers, consumer representative and telecom associations to do an intensive consideration, which took nine meetings for four months, and concluded without any outcome document.  So, what happened there?  This presentation will overview the happenings and discussion points and seek the input from community outside Japan.

sessions.name: Network Security
sessions.description:
This workshop is intended for network engineers, managers, and policy makers to understand security threats, preventions, and recovery.

Target audience

Technical staff who are now building or operating a wide area service provider network and who also wish to learn more about securing their network infrastructure.

Prerequisites

It is assumed that the workshop participants to have good knowledge of Unix/Linux and understand the general concepts related to networking and computing.
Participants are required to bring laptops with working wireless.

Workshop Topics

  1. Threat Models
    • Types of Attackers
    • Network Infrastructure
    • Service Infrastructure (e.g. DNS, email)
    • Users
  2. Network Infrastructure
    • Router and Switch Protection
    • Routing Protocol Protection
    • Detecting Sick Hosts and Walling Them
  3. Infrastructure Services
    • IDS
    • Firewalls
    • Anomaly Detection
  4. End User Hosts
    • Mac, Unix, and Linux
    • Keeping Up to Date - Patching
    • Keeping Up to Date - Patching
    • Host Based Firewalls
    • Authentication Services
    • PKI Services
    • Checking for Disease: Scanners
    • Preventing Disease: Anti-virus
    • Safe Mail Practices
    • Safe Browsing Practices in Firefox, Chrome, Safari
    • Safe Inter-host Protocols: SSH, RSVC, SFTP and more
    • Personal Encryption of Files and Communications
  5. Administrative
    • Security Plan
    • Inter-network Cooperation
      • NOGS
      • CERT
      • FIRST
    • Security Personnel
    • Planning for Future Changes

sessions.name: Network Management & Monitoring
sessions.description:
Workshop website

This is a course for those who need to manage diverse Network and NOC operations. It consists of a combination of theory and lab, with lab work on Linux constituting about 60% of the total course.

Target audience

Engineers and system staff at ISPs and large networks, including academic networks, who are involved with system management, network monitoring and management, and problem response. The course is for those who need to manage diverse Network and NOC operations.

Prerequisites

Participants are assumed to have good knowledge of the Unix/Linux command line environment, and understand the general concepts related to networking and IPv4 addressing.
Please note: Participants are required to bring laptops.

Class Size

This class is suitable for class sizes up to 36 students.

Workshop Topics

The workshop will be a combination of theory and lab. Ubuntu Linux server version 16.04 LTS will be the workshop platform. The course will cover:

  1. Introduction to Network Monitoring and Management
  2. Recap of Linux command line use. Depending on the class level this may be very basic to more in-depth. Potential topics include:
    • Introduction to Linux
    • TCP/IP network essentials
    • Security essentials including SSH
    • Linux commands and the command line interface (CLI)
    • Text editors (vi, nano)
  3. Cisco IOS Configuration Basics
  4. SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol)
  5. Installation, configuration and understanding of output of some or all of the following network monitoring and management tools:
    • LibreNMS - Automated Network Monitoring and discovery
    • Smokeping - Latency/Round Trip Time, Jitter and packet loss monitor
    • Nagios - Server and Service monitoring and alerting
    • Netflow, NfSen - traffic analysis and exploration
    • RANCID: network equipment configuration backup, change tracking & automation including the use of WebSVN
    • Network Operation Center (NOCs)
  6. Network Documentation
    • Netdot (Network Documentation Tool)
    • RT (Request Tracker): Ticketing systems for helpdesk /support and integration of RT and Nagios to automatically generate tickets.
  7. Log management: Collecting logs, monitoring them, using forensic tools and pattern matching utilities to alert when there are problems:
    • syslog / rsyslog
    • Tenshi
  8. Simulated network attack and detection using installed tools

sessions.name: APIX Meeting
sessions.description:
APIX is the association of Internet Exchange Points in the Asia Pacific Region. It serves as a forum for Internet Exchange Points to exchange experiences. APIX members meet twice a year, at the APNIC and APRICOT conferences.

More information about this session is available here.

sessions.name: Cooperation SIG
sessions.description:
The Cooperation SIG is a forum for discussion about broader Internet issues like Public Policy and Internet Governance, which are related to APNIC community interests, but which involve governments, other organizations, and other communities. The Secretariat will report to the SIG about APNIC’s outreach activities and seek advice and guidance on future activities. The SIG will act as a forum to develop and clarify the APNIC community's position on issues of relevance to the public sector, or on matters for which a community position has been sought.

An election will be held for the position of SIG Chair during this session.

sessions.name: APNIC NIR SIG
sessions.description:
The charter of the NIR SIG is to share information relating to the operations, policies, and procedures of National Internet Registries with the aim of promoting close cooperation among the NIRs and between the NIRs and the APNIC Secretariat.

An election will be held for the positions of NIR SIG Chair and Co-Chair during this NIR SIG session.

sessions.name: APNIC Services
sessions.description: This is a forum for APNIC Members, other stakeholders, and the Secretariat to discuss existing and upcoming services.

sessions.name: APNIC Policy SIG 1
sessions.description:
The charter of the Policy SIG is to develop policies and procedures which relate to the management and use of Internet address resources by APNIC, NIRs, and ISPs within the Asia Pacific region.

An election will be held for the position of Policy SIG Chair during this Policy SIG session.

sessions.name: APNIC Policy SIG 2
sessions.description: The charter of the Policy SIG is to develop policies and procedures which relate to the management and use of Internet address resources by APNIC, NIRs, and ISPs within the Asia Pacific region.

sessions.name: APNIC Global Reports
sessions.description: The Global Reports provide updates on activities, policy proposals, services, operations, and upcoming events in other regions.

sessions.name: APNIC AGM 1
sessions.description: The APNIC Executive Council (EC) invites all APNIC Members and interested members of the community to attend the APNIC Annual General Meeting (AGM) in person or remotely. At the AGM, APNIC’s plans, budgets and reports are presented to the community, and questions and feedback to both the EC and APNIC Secretariat are encouraged. APNIC EC election results are also announced during the AGM.

sessions.name: APNIC AGM 2
sessions.description: The APNIC Executive Council (EC) invites all APNIC Members and interested members of the community to attend the APNIC Annual General Meeting (AGM) in person or remotely. At the AGM, APNIC’s plans, budgets and reports are presented to the community, and questions and feedback to both the EC and APNIC Secretariat are encouraged. APNIC EC election results are also announced during the AGM.
